name: nytimes
text:
The coronavirus toll keeps mounting: More than 1.7 million people in the U.S. have contracted the virus and more than 100,000 have died. 

The virus continues to spread widely in the U.S., even as the growth of the virus is slowing in some areas. 
https://t.co/UXe8HrOTCK https://t.co/IyiOkselJS

name: nytimes
text: The Northeast U.S., especially New York and New Jersey, was the epicenter of the virus for months. But new outbreaks have shifted to the South, where many counties have seen a marked increase in cases over the past two weeks. https://t.co/ejBi7yPKaF https://t.co/JPPUfvG9RV

name: nytimes
text: In Colquitt County, Georgia, the average number of new cases per day has more than quadrupled over the past 14 days. https://t.co/ejBi7yPKaF https://t.co/CeXUDhg9CI

name: nytimes
text:
In Bullock County, Alabama, the average number of new cases per day has increased more than tenfold over the past 14 days. 

The average number of new cases has more than tripled in Acadia Parish, Louisiana.
https://t.co/ejBi7yPKaF https://t.co/C4RbYzgjCh

name: nytimes
text:
See which areas of the country are experiencing increases in coronavirus cases and where the number of new cases has subsided.  

We’re tracking the details of every coronavirus case in the U.S. and updating our numbers several times a day.
https://t.co/ejBi7yPKaF

name: nytimes
text:

https://t.co/fQw7JqocEC

name: nytimes
text: The CDC posted new recommendations on the safest way for American employers reopening their offices to prevent the spread of the coronavirus https://t.co/TRRNe40H4T

name: nytimes
text: Rev. Michael McGivney moved a step closer to sainthood on Thursday, the Vatican announced https://t.co/uoMwEhifT2

name: nytimes
text: RT @jeligon: NEW: The corner where George Floyd died was designed to keep black people away. Dozens of homes there have deeds prohibiting black residents. Those deeds helped make Minneapolis one of the nation's most racially unequal cities. w/@matt_furber @abscribe  https://t.co/Cy9Qq34wuy

name: nytimes
text:
Republicans planning their party’s convention gave North Carolina’s governor a deadline of June 3 to approve safety measures to prevent the spread of the coronavirus during the event
https://t.co/6UsScrTsOJ

name: nytimes
text:
RT @bencasselman: Unemployment benefits and other government aid programs have been a vital lifeline for millions of displaced workers during this crisis.

If Congress doesn't act soon, that lifeline could snap.
https://t.co/WitORuKO8d

name: nytimes
text: The U.S. House overwhelmingly approved legislation that would relax the terms of a federal loan program intended to help small businesses weather the pandemic, giving companies more time and flexibility to use the money https://t.co/cJmfKZeg0j

name: nytimes
text:
RT @anniekarni: “What was missing in 2016 was a real concerted effort to take the voices of real people who have deep reservations about Trump, but who identify as Republicans, and allow them to be the messengers.”

https://t.co/4K8I1oXfaz via @NYTimes

name: nytimes
text:
—The pandemic’s pace is accelerating, especially in Asia and Latin America
—Pandemic relief programs, a lifeline for Americans, could run out this summer
—The Philippines reported a single-day record of 539 new cases

text: RT @abscribe: Minneapolis precinct set aflame on the third night of protests: https://t.co/ka82t6sikL

name: nytimes
text: News Analysis: Ignoring threats from Washington, China stripped another layer of autonomy from Hong Kong on Thursday. Relations between the U.S. and China keep getting worse, despite a few moments of conciliation along the way. https://t.co/a4tGsKU1qk

name: nytimes
text: The City of Minneapolis warned protesters to stay away from the Police Department’s Third Precinct, saying on Twitter that there had been unconfirmed reports of cut gas lines and explosives in the building https://t.co/O4yqepx2S7

name: nytimes
text: RT @llerer: “America has a long tradition of honoring its fallen. We award Gold Stars and build monuments, we stand for moments of silence and sit at memorials. But in the face of these 100,000 deaths, Americans have been left to their trauma. To mourn, alone.” https://t.co/uijSpbDtQ1

name: nytimes
text: Annoyed at their government, the French have taken to the streets brandishing drinks https://t.co/eGu3kcuihc

name: nytimes
text: The State Capitol in Denver was put on lockdown after someone fired a gun near a peaceful demonstration, and protests in Columbus, Ohio, turned chaotic as crowds surged up the steps of the State Capitol and broke windows, videos showed https://t.co/YwRpaIFCu3

name: nytimes
text: Shots were fired during a protest in Louisville, Kentucky, as tensions continued to escalate in the city. Protesters had gathered in the streets to call for justice in the fatal shooting of Breonna Taylor by 3 white police officers in March. https://t.co/Yi7dJJox6V

name: nytimes
text: RT @rickgladstone: How Mr. Trump's order threatening Twitter could boomerang on him. “If platforms were not immune under the law, then they would not risk the legal liability that could come with hosting Donald Trump’s lies, defamation and threats.” @peterbakernyt @daiwaka https://t.co/ZjnL415Ich

name: nytimes
text: President Trump called the Minneapolis protesters “thugs” and threatened to intervene. “When the looting starts, the shooting starts,” he said. https://t.co/HkqX4o0WhH
